9.4 is not compatible. `HashLoginService::putUser` was deprecated.

```
[ERROR] [Error] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-livy/client-http/src/test/scala/org/apache/livy/client/http/LivyConnectionSpec.scala:41: value putUser is not a member of org.eclipse.jetty.security.HashLoginService
```

There's more info on how to address in [this StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/a/73497297/5141922).
Similar to #363 Jetty 9.4 is not compatible.

This patch doesn't quite work since the `2.12.7.1` "microversion" is only released for the `jackson-databind` artifact and this patch impacts all `jackson` dependencies.

Release notes here: https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson/wiki/Jackson-Release-2.12#micro-patches

Livy will try to find out repl jars from:
1, livy.repl.jars config
2, if  livy.repl.jars not set, will find from LIVY_HOME/repl_2.11-jars or
LIVY_HOME/repl_2.12-jars
you may check those first.

> I am not sure about the change, as this does not involve only the thriftserver module, but all interactive sessions. If the problem involves all interactive sessions, then it is ok, otherwise the fix is probably not the correct one. Can you check if the same issue affects all interactive jobs? If so, I think we can go ahead with this PR, but I would recommend a different reviewer more familiar with the code in rsc, otherwise, the fix needs to be done only on the thriftserver part and we need more investigation to understand why normal interactive sessions do not have the issue while thriftserver has. Thanks.

The same issue doesn't affect interactive jobs which created by REST API. The is because the handle functions are different in the driver. The REST API uses `handle(ctx: ChannelHandlerContext, msg: BaseProtocol.ReplJobRequest)` in the ReplDriver while thrift API uses `handle(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, JobRequest<?> msg)` in the RSCDRiver.  
ReplDriver changes state when execute code by invoking stateChangedCallback which broadcast the state to all RPC clients. 
RSCDriver does not broadcast  state to RPC clients. 
I think this patch would not affect other interactive jobs except using thrift API.

This fix is causing many changes. The `submit` method is used for many purposes, such as adding jar, files, so I do not think is a good idea to have a fix that has such a large impact on other cases that should not be affected. The current fix would also set to busy when fetching the results, and executing schema operations, and even while unregistering a session...

I think a better place for the fix would be `SqlJob`, although it is not a perfect solution either. So I would be very happy if someone comes with a better alternative.

I've realized that the current LdapAuthenticationHandler in Livy is exact copy of LdapAuthenticationHandler from Hadoop which also does not support different ways to use LDAP.
So my fix would help only with my case but it's not enough to properly implement different LDAP configurations so it's not worth merging.

@gyogal Yep I noticed that too as I work on #392. I initially thought it was related to my changes, but then noticed the failures on the main branch after this PR got merged in. I'm not quite sure what's going on as the unit tests ran fine in the PR.

Fixed the `java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError` error with additional exclusions. 

Unit tests are failing, however I think it's due to a flaky test based on behavior observed in CI where unit tests pass on the PR but fail once merged into master and vice-cersa.

There's an old [mailing list thread](https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@livy.incubator.apache.org/msg00794.html) that also discusses the issue, but with no resolution.

```
The second error, TestSparkClient.testJobSubmission, is random. I see the
failure ~25% of the times. As it turned out, the Echo job was returning,
sometimes, even before we added the listener on the job handle. So the
listener.onJobStarted method is not invoked. This can be fixed in multiple
ways but I updated the Echo job, which used to simply return its attribute
value, to do what ScalaEcho job is doing. So the Echo job now returns
"jc.sc().parallelize(list,
1).collect().get(0);". Even this could still be fast enough to cause the
same error. However I couldn't reproduce it again. Also the updated code is
taking ~1 sec or more on spark's side. So hopefully this should be ok.
```
